chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Phil. And I'm Beth. Love it or hate it, there's no doubt fast food is popular. Are you a fast food fan, Beth? Not really, no. I think sometimes it can be quite convenient, obviously because it's quick, but not really.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: Whatever you think about them, fast food brands like KFC, Domino's and of course the big one, McDonald's, are incredibly successful. In this programme, we'll be discussing the global spread of fast food from its beginnings in 1950s America. As usual, we'll be learning some useful new words and phrases. But first, I have a question for you, Beth. Roughly how many fast food restaurants are there in the UK? Is it a

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: I'm going to go for B, 42,000. OK, well later on we'll find out the answer. In the United States, cheap and easy food like hamburgers, french fries and milkshakes have been popular since the 1950s. Listen as Adam Chandler, author of the book Drive Through Dreams, which traces the history of American fast food, tells BBC

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: World Service programme The Food Chain how it all got started. At the heart of the story of fast food is a very anyone can do this sense. A lot of the company founders didn't have a college degree, who didn't have a high school degree in a lot of instances, didn't come for money, were oftentimes just people who were ready to plug themselves into a system that would work for them. And it did. It made opportunity very, very

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: easy in a time when that was a new part of the American experience. So it was the American dream in a very small way that became the American dream in a very big way. The rise of fast food reflected the rise of American economic power after the Second World War. When Adam says that this lies at the heart of the story, he means it's the most important part of the story.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: As we know today, we're just beginning. Anyone with a can do attitude could sell fast food. A can do attitude describes someone who is confident and determined to fix problems and achieve results, which is exactly what happened at successful restaurants like Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonald's. For many, these fast food brands symbolized the American dream, the idea that anyone in the United States can achieve success through hard work.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: The success of KFC, McDonald's and the rest wasn't limited to America. Nowadays, you can visit two McDonald's on opposite sides of the planet and eat exactly the same meal.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: There's been a longstanding burger culture in Iceland. They have their own take on the hamburger, wherein they'll use lettuce and raw cucumbers and a type of fry sauce. That's called a shopu bogari or shop burger. And that's been around for ages.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: We struggled to try to maintain a market. The final nail in the coffin was the global financial crisis in 2008, 2009. Iceland already had a longstanding tradition of eating burgers, a tradition that had existed for a long time. For example, the shopu bogari or shop burger was a take on or variation of the American hamburger. McDonald's weren't as successful in Iceland as they'd been

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: elsewhere. And the global financial crash of 2008 was the final nail in the coffin, an event which caused the failure of something that had already started to go wrong. To this day, there are no McDonald's in Iceland, unlike Britain, which reminds me of your question, Phil. Yes, I asked you how many fast food restaurants there are in Britain. I asked you if there were four thousand, forty two thousand or four million.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: Of course, the answer is forty two thousand, so you were right. Well done. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt, starting with at the heart of, meaning the most important part or the cause of something.

chunks.episode_title: How the world learned to love fast food
chunks.chunk_text: The adjective longstanding means having existed for a long time. A take on something means a variation or new way of presenting it. And finally, the idiom the final nail in the coffin refers to an event that causes the final end of something that had already started to fail. Once again, our six minutes are up.
